title: F-15063
text:
F-15,063 is an orally active potential <a href="antipsychotic">antipsychotic</a>, and an <a href="antagonist">antagonist</a> at the <a href="Dopamine%20receptor%20D2">D2</a>/<a href="Dopamine%20receptor%20D3">D3</a> receptors, <a href="partial%20agonist">partial agonist</a> at the <a href="Dopamine%20receptor%20D4">D4</a> receptor, and agonist at the <a href="5-HT1A%20receptor">5-HT1A</a> receptors. It has greater efficacy at the 5-HT1A receptors than other antipsychotics, such as <a href="clozapine">clozapine</a>, <a href="aripiprazole">aripiprazole</a>, and <a href="ziprasidone">ziprasidone</a>. This greater efficacy may lead to enhanced antipsychotic properties, as antipsychotics that lack 5-HT1A affinity are associated with increased risk of <a href="extrapyramidal%20symptoms">extrapyramidal symptoms</a>, and lack of activity against the negative symptoms of <a href="schizophrenia">schizophrenia</a>.
As expression of <a href="Immediate%20early%20gene">immediate-early gene</a> (IEG) in certain brain regions may represent markers of anti-psychotic activity, expression of immediate-early gene <a href="mRNA">mRNA</a> in the <a href="prefrontal%20cortex">prefrontal cortex</a> and <a href="striatum">striatum</a> was measured. Treatment with F-15,063 resulted in induction of "<a href="c-fos">c-fos</a>" and "<a href="fosB">fosB</a>" mRNA expression in the prefrontal cortex. In the striatum, F-15,063 treatment resulted in induction of all 
IEGs studied ("c-fos, fosB, <a href="zif268">zif268</a>, <a href="c-jun">c-jun</a>, <a href="JUNB">junB</a>, <a href="NOR1">nor1</a>, <a href="nur77">nur77</a>, <a href="Arc%20%28protein%29">arc</a>").
F-15,063 was tested in several animal models that predict antipsychotic activity to help determine the behavioral profile. Administration of F-15,063 blocked <a href="amphetamine">amphetamine</a> and <a href="ketamine">ketamine</a> induced hyperlocomotion, but did not affect baseline, spontaneous locomotor activity. In addition, F-15,063 did not produce <a href="catalepsy">catalepsy</a>, a side effect of other antipsychotics, such as <a href="haloperidol">haloperidol</a>. This inhibition of catalepsy is 5-HT1A receptor mediated, as pretreatment with the 5-HT1A antagonist <a href="WAY-100635">WAY-100635</a> reinstated catalepsy. The level of catalepsy did not increase with chronic dosing, and there was no evidence for <a href="serotonin%20syndrome">serotonin syndrome</a> at clinically relevant doses.
Plasma levels of F-15,063 decreased seven-fold 4 hours after oral administration, and 25-fold after 8 hours. Despite this, there was still a high (65%) level of central D2 occupancy at 4 hours, and it retained its full antipsychotic potential at this time point. Even after 8 hours, F-15,063 still demonstrated some central D2 occupancy, and retained some antipsychotic activity.
